detailsOfAchievement: Founded in 1993, Shelter Associates is an NGO with major activities in the following areas: housing for the urban poor, urban sanitation, poverty mapping (using GIS and remote sensing technology), research and documentation, advocacy for the urban poor, and community mobilization. Shelter Associates works closely with Baandhani, an informal CBO of slum dwellers and the backbone of Shelterâ€™s community mobilization effort. Baandhani is involved in all of Shelterâ€™s activities. SA approaches these projects through a holistic lens of city-planning. Shelter believes in creating sustainable and replicable models. Planning for the urban poor must be integrated with mainstream city planning to prevent duplication of activities and to ensure optimum utilization and amalgamation of existing and planned projects and resources. SA ensures that national programs truly reach the poor, working with local, state, and central government bodies to be sure that all IHSDP projects directly serve them. A more recent example of this is the IHSDP project under the JNNURM program being implemented in Sangli. SA has also participated in the Nirmal Bharat Abhiyan (national program) providing toilets for the urban poor. SA focuses on advocacy in order to guarantee that plans are directly converted into policies. In this way, a database is being created that locally positions the poor on city maps, providing them with visibility and recognition as legitimate citizens of their cities and greater nation. Shelter Associates has more recently focused its efforts in the smaller cities and Maharashtra because it is in these locations that a holistic approach works best. The incentive is to prevent these cities from reaching the scale of problems which have plagued the larger cities of Mumbai, Pune, and other metros of India. Shelterâ€™s work has been recognized by UNCHS (United Nations Center for Human Settlements) as one of the Good Practices. Shelterâ€™s holistic approach to using IHSDP funds to create a slum-free city in Sangli has been adopted in the Rajiv Gandhi Awas Yojana. Additionally, Shelter Associates Director Pratima Joshi has received an Ashoka Global Fellowship and has been featured in the BBCâ€™s Asia Week. She was distinguished through the Singapore Strait Timesâ€™ â€œNew Asian Heroesâ€, recognizing individuals in Asia who are making a difference in society.

detailsOfAchievement: 1.NAAC Re Accreditation 2.BEST COLLEGE AWARD 3.DST FIST PROGRAM 4.DST SERB FELLOWSHIP 5.DBT FOLDSCOPE PROJECT 6.UGC POST DOCTORAL FELLOWSHIP 7.22 MRPs 8.200 research papers 9.07 MoUs 10.Patent filed 11.University award in Cultural programs 12.Rain water harvesting system, roof top solar photovoltaic system, solar hot water system, green campus

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Project aims to isolate and identify the endophytic mycoflora from anti cancer plants by using Foldscope-a new invention by Department of Biotechnology, Govt. of India. Anti cancer plants like Turmeric, Catharanthys, Azadiracta Indica, Murrya Species were collected from different parts of Maharashtra and checked for the presence of fungal endophytes using Foldscope. Further work was extended for the biochemical analysis of the fungi for their efficacy to produce different anti cancer chemicals.

The project aims 1)to develop the method for excision of embryo and their germination on nutrient medium under in-vitro condition. 2)to standardize condition for development of seeding and their hardening. 3)to develop the nursery technique for preparation of seedlings,their transfer and survival in field conditions. The developed method can be used for reforestation of hilly barren land of low rain fall area and conservation of endangered medicinally important tree species.
UGC XIIth Plan Grants were received under the budget heads of Books, Equipment, Annual Maintenance Contract

UGC XIIth Plan Grants were received under the budget heads of Books, Equipment, Instrumentation Maintenance Facility (Annual Maintenance Contract of UPS) and Improvement of Existing premises(Reading hall tables and Library Counter Furniture).
The DST-FIST Grants received will be utilized for the development of basic research in science as well as to develop laboratory infrastructure for undergraduate and postgraduate students.

detailsOfAchievement: Since the inception of our Karjat project in 2006, we have successfully assisted off the roads 7058 wandering mentally-ill roadside destitutes till the end of 2019, treated them and finally reunited them with their families in far flung villages and towns of India (more than 8500 destitutes have been reunited in last 32 years). More of our details can be found on our website - www.shraddharehabilitationfoundation.org Dr Bharat Vatwani has been conferred with the RAMON MAGSAYSAY AWARD in 2018.

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Source of funds are donations in cheque or cash, interests on FD and interests on S.B. Account. Our NGO rescues the wandering mentally ill destitutes on the streets, provides them with food, shelter, care and appropriate psychiatric treatment. Once psychiatric well being is achieved, these destitutes are reunited with their families in far flung villages and corners of India.

detailsOfAchievement: Krishi Vigyan Kendra, Durgapur, Dist. Amravati has been established in July,1995 with the responsibilities to bring forth agricultural vis-a vis rural development in the area through its mandated activities on training, front line demonstrations and on farm testing/adaptive trials. Ever since it became functional in the year 1996, it has made several innovative interventions in the agricultural development process of the district. Shram Sadhana, Amravati being a pioneer voluntary organization in the field of women and child development and water conservation work, the major focus was to develop the villages facing acute shortage of irrigation water to fulfill the minimum requirements of the farmers. Keeping this aspect in view, KVK applied its efforts to develop rain water harvesting models. KVK has introduced various water conservation models such as small farm ponds, Gabbian structures, Wanrai bandhara, and low cost rain water harvesting structures benefitting 158 farmers from Isambri village. The model developed by KVK as part of demonstrating rain water harvesting technologies has become a living example and it is replicated by State Department of Agriculture as â€œIsambri Modelâ€ after the name of the village where 441 TCM rain water was harvested by using all water conservation structures. Development of farming system module for rainfed farmers, sustainable dry land agriculture, in-situ soil and water conservation practices to increase productivity in rainfed conditions, up-gradation of local goat by Usmanabadi buck are only few of the numerous contributions made by the kendra within a short span of time. KVK focused its directions towards Integrated Pest Management (IPM) in cotton and chickpea with the concept of block demonstrations. The villages namely Kohala Jateshwar, Nimbhora, Pala, Kajana, Khartalegaon, Sawarkhed, Kumagarh, Lehgaon, etc. are developed as IPM villages. This technology is being practiced on more than 500 ha of area in these villages and diffusion of technology is observed in every village of the district. The average cost of cultivation of IPM farmer reduced to ` 6300 per acre as compared to ` 7900 per acre before IPM with 28 per cent increase in productivity. Application of chemical pesticide sprays have been reduced to 2 to 3 as compared to 8 to 10 before IPM. More than 45 per cent increase in net income is observed in IPM trained farmers. Now, the KVK is identified as a resource centre for IPM technology particularly in cotton, chickpea, soybean and Nagpur Mandarin. Krishi Vigyan Kendra has also established a Model Farm to disseminate and demonstrate the agro techniques suitable to the local farming community in the district for sustainable development. This model farm, equipped with modern irrigation system has important horticultural crops like guava, sweet Nagpur Mandarin, Nagpur Mandarin, sapota, custard apple and mango developed on 4 ha area to cater to the need of farmers in the district. Out of the total land 6 ha is utilized for crop production purpose like crop cafeteria, seed production, technology demonstrations, farm trials, etc. Fodder crops are cultivated on 1 ha area and teak is planted on 0.80 ha land. The instructional farm also acts as a technology assessment centre before their transfer to the farmers of the operational area. The training cum demonstration units like nursery, fruit and vegetable processing, vermicomposting, bio-agents and biopesticide production, mushroom cultivation, spawn production, soybean processing, Information and communication technology with video conferencing facility and animal production are established to meet the training need of farmers and in order to supply the required quality material to them. The facilities for Soil and Water testing, Phyto diagnostic, Post Harvest Technology Laboratory and an Agricultural Technology Information Centre is available with the KVK. Facility for Nagpur Mandarin rootstock DNA testing is unique contribution of the KVK developed for Nagpur Mandarin growing farmers of the area. As a Village Agriculture Knowledge Hub, KVK adopted 7 villages in Amravati district to facilitate the farmers about market information, weather information, disease information at the village level. The KVK acts as a vocational training centre to work at the grass root level for imparting need-based training and skills in the field of agriculture and rural development. KVK has offered trainings to 22430 participants by conducting 787 training programmes for its cliental with the help of its multidisciplinary team. 288 on farm trials are conducted for assessment and refinement of the recent agricultural technologies. Front line demonstrations are conducted on 1166 ha area covering 2232 farmers and in animal science 144 animals covering 144 farmers, in agriculture engineering frontline demonstrations conducted on farm implements on 143 ha area covering 196 farmers. With extension activities like Field days, Exhibitions, Kisan Mela, Diagnostic visits, Advisory services, Video Conferencing etc. KVK covered 2,17,947 farmers of the area. Helpline services and mobile messaging services are started by the KVK benefitting 9400 farmers. In order to improve the socio-economic situation of the women in agriculture and for drudgery reduction 345 women self help groups are formed. KVK has formed 142 farmers club at village level to identify and communicate their problems related to agriculture and allied activities. KVK frequently organizes meetings for interaction between scientists and farmers. This has led to increased productivity and overall output of the village and has made a concrete difference to the standard of living of the villagers. The growth of this KVK has been steady and relatively faster because, besides the support of the ICAR, it has financial as well as administrative linkages and support of the Govt. KVK is fully functional in its operational area with record achievements and has bagged award of excellence for best work done under ATMA project. Since inception the KVK has performed as lighthouse for farming community of the district and gained faith of the rural population and lot of reliability and trust of the farmers.

detailsOfAchievement: The activities were initiated in 1987 in 22 villages in Jaoli taluka of Satara district in Maharashtra state. The period from 1987 to 1995 was dedicated to rehabilitation of families who had foregone their lands in Koyna dam. The activities were aimed at confidence building as well as undertaking measures for economic upliftment such as dairy development and agriculture development. The field insights gained affirmed womenâ€™s empowerment as a thrust right from the initial stages of the organization. Another crucial strategy adopted was channelizing the government schemes for the real needy whereby dissemination about the government schemes was undertaken for the needy and eligible, and proactive initiatives were undertaken to link these 2. The second phase begun with registration of Shramik as a formal entity. This phase spans from years 1995 to 2005. A salient characteristic of this phase was fostering of various community organizations such as cooperatives so that they become the vibrant nodes of community mobilization and transformation. Intense capacity building measures were planned and undertaken for the community organizations which were in the form of womenâ€™s Self-Help Groups, Farmersâ€™ Cooperatives, tribalâ€™ cooperatives, etc. The third phase (2005- till date) was characterized by strengthening of these community organisations and their empowerment. The focus on womenâ€™s empowerment was bolstered further through legal awareness (for example- Domestic Violence Act, Pre Conception, Pre Natal Diagnostic Technique (PCPNDT) Act) and specific livelihoods projects for them which can result in betterment of their health too (such as manufacturing of low cost sanitary napkins). This phase also saw strengthening of the environmental initiatives. Another important facet was reinforced emphasis on tribal development which lead to initiation of the organizationâ€™s work in one of the most impoverished tribal areas in the country- Jawhar taluka in Thane district. Moreover, there were efforts to replicate the concept in greater geographical canvass furthering the work in greater number of villages and area- which included, apart from Thane district, Raigad district in Maharashtra. â€¢ Vision and Mission Statement of Organization Vision: Basic necessities of all the populations are fulfilled so that everybody, especially the deprived populations, will have a life of dignity. Mission: Focus on the progress of human being and surrounding natural ambience by generating awareness of local problems and resources and, through the participation of people, fostering their social and economic development. â€¢ Goal of the Organization Social and economic development with environmental balance and improved health of economically backward deprived sections of the society through their empowerment. â€¢ Objectives: 1. Create confidence in human beings that they are in driverâ€™s seat of their own life. 2. Centralize progress of development around common man & make them aware about his problems. 3. Study various government schemes & programs to provide its information to ordinary people and implement these schemes with peopleâ€™s participation. 4. Create awareness in rural area about environment balance. 5. Creating new models of economical development building on local resources like forest, land & water. 6. Fostering groups of youths and provide them training
